709718f-a.text:
East side of Seventh Avenue, 25th to 24th Streets.
August 25, 1927.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

711771f-a.text:
251-233 West 24th Street, north side, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, seen across clearing at 2(6)7 West 23rd Street.The large building at right is the Jeanne D'Arc Home for Girls.
June 3, 1930

P. L. Sperr.

711768f-a.text:
(1)
West 24th Street, north side, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, showing Public School No. 45 at No. 225 West 24th Street. This building in conjunction with the structures at the left (No's. 233 to 239 inclusive) will be razed in 1937-8 to provide a new high school site with a 250 foot front on this street, thru to West 25th Street. The three houses on the right (No's. 219 to 223) will remain.
March 6, 1931
P. L. Sperr

(2)
A more extensive view of the former school site in the opposite direction from No. 1. The photographer is viewing eastward to show the 6 story apartment building appearing at the left is the Jeanne D'Arc Home for Girls and is No. 251-255, slightly to the east of Eighth Avenue.
March 21, 1938

(3)
A due northward view thru the former school site. The large left structures seen face on the south side of West 26th Street; their rears appearing here.
March 21, 1938
P. L. Sperr

711769f-a.text:
(1)
237-249 West 24th Street, north side, between Seventh and Eighth Avenue.
March 6, 1931
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, slightly more inclusive. Buildings shown are Nos 249 (extreme left) to 233 (3-story building extreme right). Note the Empire State Building tower in the background.
December 26, 1936
P.L. Sperr.

1507643-a.folder: Seventh Avenue #229-25 - 23rd Street looking east, Manhattan, NY
1507643-a.title: Seventh Avenue #229-25 - 23rd Street looking east

1507645-a.folder: Seventh Avenue #229-25 - 23rd Street looking east, Manhattan, NY
1507645-a.title: Seventh Avenue #229-25 - 23rd Street looking east

709717f-a.text:
An Unfortunate Incident in a Great Engineering Task

(The scene is Seventh Ave., N.Y.C., at Twenty-fourth St., just after an explosion has caused the street to collapse for an entire block. It is particularly interesting as showing graphically how the metropolis is being honeycombed for its underground transportation system. In order not to interfere with the ordinary use of the streets during the three years necessary to complete the work, the tunneling method is used rather than open excavation work. For a long period after the earth has been dug up and before the steel & concrete work is completed, the surface of the street is merely boards propped up by wooden beams. An extra-heavy blast, with perhaps other contributing factors, caused the supports to collapse, and the whole street - with its occupants, including a crowded street car - dropped to the bottom. Seven persons were killed & scores seriously injured. There are forty-five miles of subway under construction in New York, one line being under the most important & congested thoroughfare, Broadway. Three days after the accident shown in this illustration, a second one - somewhat
less serious - occurred on Broadway)
